moves.1. c4: The game starts with c2-c4, the English opening, a threatening move to black.
moves.1... c6: I countered this with the c7-c6 as if d2-d3 happened I could support d7-d5 keep my share of the centre.
moves.2. d4: Unless black goes d7-d5 it is a sticky situation, as white has control of the centre.
moves.7. b4: b4, blocking the pawn on b5 to advance and threaten knight.
moves.7... a5: a5 challenging the pawn on a5.
moves.8. Bf4: Bishop is brought out to attack the knight on b8 making my rook take in leaving the pawn on b5 open to attack.
moves.8... Ne4: Knight is creating a threat, Nc3 can take it or move.  Then  d5-e4 would happen attacking the knight on f3 giving black an move to develop.
moves.9. Nxe4 dxe4: The pawn takes e4 endangering the knight.
moves.10. Nd2: The knight retreats, leaving a isolated pawn on e4.
moves.10... Qxd4: Queen takes the free pawn. Securing the pawn on e4 therefore next move would be e4-e3 if bxb8 then rxb8, happened.
moves.11... Rxb8: a1-b1 leaving the pawn on c5 unprotected.
moves.12. bxa5 e3: Pawn on e3 now poses threat to knight on d2.
moves.14. Nf3: Knight moved out opening up the queen on d1.
moves.14... Qc3+: Checking the king hoping for a move to e2, so then bishop on e7 can take the pawn on c5.
moves.15. Kf2: What I had hoped for! (forced move)
moves.15... Bxc5+ 16. Kg3: The king is now out in the open with the bishop on c8 presenting a threat if pawn on e6 is advanced.
moves.16... Qe3: Queen to e3 to attack the king for g2.
moves.17. Qd3: A queen for queen trade is offered.
moves.17... Qf2+: The offer is declined and I stuck with the original plan.
moves.18... e5+: e6 to e5 now put the king in check with the only reasonably possibility of the pawn on g4 advancing.
moves.19. g4 h5: This is a key move in the game, as the pawn on h5 is now attacking the pawn on g4 with the bishop on c8 backing it up. Creating a forced checkmate unless white moves queen to f5.
moves.20. Qf5 Bxf5: The queen is exchanged for a bishop and I plan the move up the pawns on f7 and g7 to continue the checkmate and the king is still unable to move anywhere.
moves.21. gxf5 f6: Pawn to f6 to back up when I move the pawn to g5 because of the knight.
moves.22. Rc1: Castle creating a false threat to my bishop but if white decides to take my bishop the queen will take it back but this allows the king to move itself out.
moves.23... e4: The pawn now endangers the knight on f3.
moves.24. Nh4 Qe3+: Check! and the castle on c1 is lost.
moves.25. Kg2 Qxc1 26. Nf5: Knight is moved to try and stop the advance of the pawn on h5.
moves.27. Ng3: White moves to block the check.
moves.27... h4: Now whites knight is pinned. With the pawn on h4 attacking it as well but is unable to move.
moves.28. e3: Pawn is moved up to stop the advance of e4.
moves.29. hxg3: The pawn is taken back now the rook is open to attack.
moves.30... Qxg6: Pawn is taken to prevent it moving up and creating any further annoyances.
moves.32. Be2: Bishop now guarding a few spaces.
moves.32... Kd7: The rook now is open to go to h8 and advance up, white resigns here as it would be a eventual checkmate, this is probably one of my best played games in a while. Thanks!
